Get Started with affectOU

Source: vignettes/affectOU.Rmd
affectOU.Rmd

affectOU provides tools for modeling affect dynamics using the Ornstein-Uhlenbeck (OU) process â€“ a continuous-time stochastic model that captures how emotions fluctuate around a baseline and return to equilibrium over time.

This vignette walks through the packageâ€™s core functionality: simulating the OU process, computing theoretical quantities, and fitting unidimensional models to data. See Affect Characteristics Implied by the OU Process for visual demonstrations of the modelâ€™s qualitative behaviours and their psychological interpretations.

library(affectOU)

Creating an affectOU Model

One-Dimensional Model

For a univariate affect process, the stochastic differential equation of the OU process is:

dX(t)=Î¸(Î¼âˆ’X(t))dt+Î³dW(t)d{X}(t) = {\theta}({\mu} - {X}(t))dt + {\gamma} \, d{W}(t)

Here, the parameters represent:

  • Î¸ (theta): Attractor strengthâ€”how quickly affect returns to baseline
  • Î¼ (mu): Attractor locationâ€”the baseline or â€œset pointâ€ of affect
  • Î³ (gamma): Diffusion coefficientâ€”the intensity of random perturbations

Create a simple one-dimensional model with default parameters:

model <- affectOU()
model
#> 
#> â”€â”€ 1D Ornstein-Uhlenbeck Model â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€
#> dX(t) = Î¸(Î¼ âˆ’ X(t))dt + Î³ dW(t)
#> 
#> Î¸ = 0.500, Î¼ = 0.000, Î³ = 1.000, Ïƒ = |Î³| = 1.000

Specify custom parameters to represent, for example, a process with moderate mean-reversion (Î¸\theta = 0.5), positive baseline (Î¼\mu = 1), and unit diffusion (Î³\gamma = 1):

model <- affectOU(theta = 0.5, mu = 1, gamma = 1)
model
#> 
#> â”€â”€ 1D Ornstein-Uhlenbeck Model â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€
#> dX(t) = Î¸(Î¼ âˆ’ X(t))dt + Î³ dW(t)
#> 
#> Î¸ = 0.500, Î¼ = 1.000, Î³ = 1.000, Ïƒ = |Î³| = 1.000

Multidimensional Models

The OU framework extends naturally to multiple affect dimensions (e.g., valence and arousal). For a d-dimensional process:

dğ—(t)=ğš¯(ğ›âˆ’ğ—(t))dt+ğšªdğ–(t)d\mathbf{X}(t) = \boldsymbol{\Theta}(\boldsymbol{\mu} - \mathbf{X}(t))dt + \boldsymbol{\Gamma} \, d\mathbf{W}(t)

The default is a 2D model with uncoupled dynamics (diagonal ğš¯\boldsymbol{\Theta} and ğšª\boldsymbol{\Gamma}) and identical parameters across dimensions:

model_2d <- affectOU(ndim = 2)
model_2d
#> 
#> â”€â”€ 2D Ornstein-Uhlenbeck Model â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€
#> dX(t) = Î˜(Î¼ âˆ’ X(t))dt + Î“ dW(t)
#> 
#> Î¼ = [0.000, 0.000]
#> 
#> Î˜:
#>      [,1] [,2]
#> [1,]  0.5  0.0
#> [2,]  0.0  0.5
#> 
#> Î“:
#>      [,1] [,2]
#> [1,]    1    0
#> [2,]    0    1
#> 
#> Î£ = Î“Î“áµ€:
#>      [,1] [,2]
#> [1,]    1    0
#> [2,]    0    1

Create an uncoupled 2D model with different parameters for each dimension:

model_2d <- update(model_2d,
  theta = diag(c(0.5, 0.3)), # Different regulation speeds
  mu = c(0, 1), # Different baselines
  gamma = diag(c(1, 0.8)) # Different diffusion levels
)

Above, we use update() to modify an existing model without recreating it from scratch. For coupled dynamics where dimensions influence each other, use a non-diagonal ğš¯\boldsymbol{\Theta} matrix:

theta_coupled <- matrix(c(
  0.5, 0.1,
  0.2, 0.3
), nrow = 2, byrow = TRUE)

model_coupled <- update(model_2d,
  theta = theta_coupled
)

Simulating Trajectories

simulate() generates trajectories using Euler-Maruyama discretization:

sim <- simulate(model)

Simulation settings can be customized:

sim <- simulate(
  model,
  nsim = 1, # Number of replications
  dt = 0.01, # Integration time step
  stop = 100, # Total simulation time
  save_at = 0.1, # Output sampling interval
  seed = 42 # For reproducibility
)

Visualizing Simulations

Simulated data can be explored in various ways:

# Time series trajectory (default)
plot(sim)

# Distribution of affect values
plot(sim, type = "histogram")

# Autocorrelation function with theoretical overlay
plot(sim, type = "acf")

# Phase portrait (lag-1 relationship)
plot(sim, type = "phase")

Multiple Simulations

Generate multiple independent realizations by setting nsim > 1:

sim <- simulate(model, nsim = 3)
plot(sim, type = "time")

Extracting Simulation Data

Simulated data can be extracted in different formats:

# Directly from the simulation object
data <- sim$data # 3D array (time Ã— dimension Ã— simulation)
# Using head() or tail()
head(sim, n = 3)
#>   time dim sim    value
#> 1 0.00   1   1 1.000000
#> 2 0.01   1   1 1.056281
#> 3 0.02   1   1 1.083456
# As a list of data frames (one per simulation)
sim_list <- as.list(sim)
head(sim_list[[1]], n = 3)
#>   time     dim1
#> 1 0.00 1.000000
#> 2 0.01 1.056281
#> 3 0.02 1.083456
# As a data frame (long or wide format)
sim_df <- as.data.frame(sim)
head(sim_df, n = 3)
#>   time dim sim    value
#> 1 0.00   1   1 1.000000
#> 2 0.01   1   1 1.056281
#> 3 0.02   1   1 1.083456
# As a 3D array (time Ã— dimension Ã— simulation)
sim_array <- as.array(sim)
dim(sim_array)
#> [1] 10001     1     3
# As a matrix (time Ã— dimension)
sim_matrix <- as.matrix(sim)
head(sim_matrix, n = 3)
#>      time dim sim    value
#> [1,] 0.00   1   1 1.000000
#> [2,] 0.01   1   1 1.056281
#> [3,] 0.02   1   1 1.083456

Theoretical Quantities

Model Summary

Key theoretical properties can be computed with summary():

summary(model)
#> 
#> â”€â”€ 1D Ornstein-Uhlenbeck Model â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€
#> 
#> â”€â”€ Dynamics â”€â”€
#> 
#> Stable (node)
#> 
#> â”€â”€ Stationary distribution â”€â”€
#> 
#> Mean: 1
#> SD: 1
#> Half-life: 1.386
#> Relaxation time (Ï„): 2

The summary aggregates results from stability(), stationary(), and relaxation(). Each can also be called independently for more detail:

  • Stability: Is the system stable? What type of dynamics does the system exhibit?
  • Stationary distribution: Long-run mean, SD, and (for multivariate models) covariance
  • Relaxation time: Time constant of perturbation decay (Ï„=1/Î¸\tau = 1/\theta)

For multidimensional models, the model summary also includes coupling indicators:

summary(model_coupled)
#> 
#> â”€â”€ 2D Ornstein-Uhlenbeck Model â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€
#> 
#> â”€â”€ Dynamics â”€â”€
#> 
#> Stable (node)
#> 
#> â”€â”€ Stationary distribution â”€â”€
#> 
#> Mean: [0, 1]
#> SD: [1.043, 1.167]
#> Half-life: [1.585, 2.988]
#> Relaxation time (Ï„): [2.347, 4.327]
#> 
#> â”€â”€ Structure â”€â”€
#> 
#> Coupling: Dim 1 â†’ Dim 2 (+), Dim 2 â†’ Dim 1 (+)
#> Noise: independent

Extract Equation

equation() renders the modelâ€™s stochastic differential equation in multiple formats, offering plain text, LaTeX, R expression, or code output.

cat(equation(model))
#> dX(t) = theta * (mu - X(t)) dt + gamma dW(t)
#> 
#> where:
#>   theta = 0.5
#>   mu    = 1
#>   gamma = 1
#>   sigma = 1

With evaluated parameters:

cat(equation(model, inline = TRUE))
#> dX(t) = 0.5 * (1 - X(t)) dt + 1 dW(t)

Fitting Models to Data

fit() estimates OU parameters from univariate time series using maximum likelihood:

# Generate data from known parameters
true_model <- affectOU(theta = 0.5, mu = 0, sigma = 1)
sim <- simulate(true_model, dt = 0.01, stop = 500, save_at = 0.1)

# Extract the simulated data
data <- as.data.frame(sim)

# Fit the model
fitted <- fit(true_model, data = data$value, times = data$time)
fitted
#> 
#> â”€â”€ Fitted 1D Ornstein-Uhlenbeck Model â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€
#> 5001 data points (dt â‰ˆ 0.100)
#> Î¸ = 0.443, Î¼ = 0.019, Î³ = 1.002
#> Log-likelihood: -1237.784
#> RMSE: 0.310
# Residuals over time
plot(fitted, type = "residuals")

See plot() for more details on available diagnostics and their interpretations.

Summary

The typical workflow starts with affectOU() to define a model (1D or multidimensional), optionally adjusting parameters via update(). Trajectories are generated with simulate() and visualized with plot(). Theoretical properties â€“ stability, stationary distribution, and relaxation time â€“ are available through summary() and its component functions. The modelâ€™s SDE can be rendered in several formats via equation(). For empirical data, fit() estimates parameters from univariate time series using maximum likelihood.
